author: leolara
content: In the specs (https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/blob/master/specs/fulu/fork-choice.md?plain=1#L27) if the columns are not available retrieve_column_sidecars raises an exception. In the format (http://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/blob/master/tests/formats/fork_choice/README.md?plain=1#L110) it says that if columns == [] it is to simulate that this exception is raised. If there is a better way to express that during the test retrieve_column_sidecars should raise an exception, let me know. We can change it. The idea is that we need tests that contain this circustance.

author: leolara
content: IMO, the specs would be better if instead of retrieve_column_sidecars raising a exception, it would be codified in `is_data_available` whether the columns returned are enough

author: mart1n9950
content: Hi everyone, current Ethereum protocol still faces some attacks like ex-ante reorg attack, sandwich attack, and even liveness attack. Our AA proposal can solve all these attacks entirely with little modifications. The core modification is that the block is required to point to a parent that receive one-third of attestations in its slot, which does not affect the normal situation. AA really improves the security of the system.ðŸ”¥ ðŸ”¥ ðŸ”¥

author: mart1n9950
content: If the adversary controls two continuous slots, it can easily reorganize a block with no risk. Current proposer boosting can not prevent such attack from happening.

author: mart1n9950
content: If we increase the value of proposer boosting, it increase the probability of sandwich reorg attack. Current mitigation can not prevent such attack from happening.ðŸ™Œ

author: mart1n9950
content: AA only checks whether the parent of a block recieve more than one third attestations in its slot. It is very easy to achieve for the normal validators. However, any validators that controls less than one-third can not propose a block without releasing it as the block does not receive any attestation from honest validators.

author: mart1n9950
content: AA is a provable reorg-resilient solution for Ethereum. And the property of reorg-resilient helps to prove the liveness property. Since the white paper of Gasper does not have the conventional liveness, it only prove that with high probability the system has liveness. But our mechanism can prove that the system has the real liveness. We completed the last piece of the puzzle.

author: mart1n9950
content: We really hope everyone can have a look of our proposal. It is important for the system. Not only now, but the future.

author: leolara
content:
I think no, we can leave retrieve_column_sidecars unimplemented and assume that it does return the columns that we have for the block. But instead of it throwing an exception if there are not enough columns, codify what is not enough columns in is_data_available based on assuming that retrieve_column_sidecars is returning all that the node has.

But for the short term issue that <@680234424037670912> is mentioning, what about adding `retrieve_column_sidecars_throws` to the format, would that be better? And columns = [] doesn't imply failure

author: jtraglia
content:
Sure, that's true I guess. I'm just trying to convey that we wouldn't need to worry too much about this. I agree that it would be best if all parties made this change at the fulu fork. But I would be lightly opposed to making this endpoint versioned. Maybe the following note would be sufficient?
> This endpoint was initially designed to return the execution payload (and after Deneb, blobs) to the proposer. In Fulu, the endpoint was updated to only respond with a status code, without an execution payload or blobs. This change was made due to increased blob counts in Fulu which would cause proposers to unnecessarily download large amounts of data. Note that the builder/relay is expected to broadcast the signed unblinded block and blobs to the network.

author: terencechain
content: I think the cleanest approach is to introduce something like `SubmitBlindBlockFulu` that encapsulates the new behavior. I already implemented this for Prysm and it works well. Try and error for us is more difficult and prone to bugs
